@crowder No, leaders have not wielded power this way in practice.

@crowder I disagree with further consolidating the House‚Äôs powers in a few leaders. Consolidation makes the body more partisan and less deliberative, and ultimately it has empowered people like President Trump.

@KaivanShroff @DebraMessing But also‚Ä¶https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1138617601440063489?s=21 QT @justinamash @kyledcheney 1. No such thing as a ‚Äúcivil‚Äù contempt resolution.
2. Criminal prosecution for contempt of Congress requires actual contempt vote.
3. Unlike contempt, today‚Äôs res authorizes lawsuits.
4. Terminology of members of Congress shouldn‚Äôt be emulated; both sides have incentive to hype.

@DebraMessing https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1138581732637237250?s=21 QT @justinamash #HRes430 isn‚Äôt a contempt resolution; it authorizes Rep. Nadler to file lawsuits to enforce specific subpoenas but, unfortunately, shifts to leadership the power to authorize future enforcement lawsuits, further centralizing the House‚Äôs authority and undermining the institution.
Congrats to @CityOfLasVegas‚Äô newest members, @OliviaDiazLV and @BrianCLV. I look forward to working with you to see our state succeed at both the local and federal levels.

@crowder @kyledcheney Unlike a contempt resolution, #HRes430 does not hold anyone in contempt of Congress. It allows for lawsuits to enforce subpoenas. Civil contempt of court is a possible outcome from this process, but this resolution does not in itself produce that outcome.

Voice voting is the quickest way to vote on something because we don't have to tally each Rep's vote. It's typically used when there's broad consensus on a vote or issue. It is the right of any Rep to request a recorded vote even if a voice vote is proposed.
En bloc is when we bundle noncontroversial amendments together and vote on them all at once. The Chair of the subcommittee provides an overview of the en bloc package before we vote on it.

The language for the TAL has been amended and adopted. It was a very quick process for this subcommittee's mark because it had broad bipartisan support and noncontroversial amendments. Because of that, the committee adopted the amendments en bloc and voice voted the mark.

Right now, health coverage is determined by your zip code. That is wrong. Medicaid and state mandates vary drastically, and if our goal is universal coverage, we can no longer have a system where states decide what benefits to cover. #Med4America

Beyond adding dental, vision, and hearing, #Med4America includes Long-Term Services and Supports‚Äîone the most important benefits we include. No health system is truly universal unless it covers LTSS. Check out Section 2203 and Part B. #AllMeansAll https://delauro.house.gov/sites/delauro.house.gov/files/Medicare_for_America_Act_.pdf

Many have said Medicaid for all would be better because the benefits covered are better than Medicare. That‚Äôs why the #Med4America benefits package is based on Connecticut‚Äôs HUSKY. This extensive list ensures that every American has the same strong set of benefits.

#Med4America expands Medicare to include an extensive benefits package, caps premiums & out-of-pocket costs, will have no deductibles, and gives Medicare the power to bring down high drug costs. In short, it would ensure everyone has access to high-quality, affordable coverage.

Glad to see the House @WaysMeansCmte debate universal healthcare coverage today. That is the goal we must achieve, and my bill with @RepSchakowsky, Medicare for America, would achieve that goal. https://delauro.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/delauro-schakowsky-reintroduce-medicare-america

Congress can and should do better. Changing this broken funding process is a critical step to tackling the $22 trillion national debt crisis. We will not solve this debt crisis until and unless we fix our broken funding process. #gapol

Fifth, it will require the Senate Budget Committee to produce a five-year, bipartisan plan every two years. The plan will include targets for the ratio of public debt-to-GDP, discretionary spending, mandatory spending, and federal revenues.

Second, it will match the fiscal year w/ the calendar year & end ‚Äúvote-a-rama.‚Äù

Third, the funding agreement will only require 302a allocations to set top-line spending levels for each two-year period.

Fourth, it will make the funding agreement a law, instead of a resolution.

The Fix Funding First Act will do five things:

First, it will impose consequences on Members of Congress for failing to get the job done on time, such as ‚ÄúNo Funding, No Recess,‚Äù and ‚ÄúNo Funding, No Pay.‚Äù #gapol

That‚Äôs completely unacceptable. We need a politically neutral platform that funds the government on time every year. The only way to get there is with real consequences for Members of Congress if they don‚Äôt get the job done. We also need structural changes to the process.

Congress has only funded the government on time four times since the Budget Act of 1974 became law, and the last time was in 1996. 

On top of that, Congress has kicked the can down the road with 186 continuing resolutions and allowed 21 government shutdowns.
THREAD: Anyone can see that the funding process used by Congress is totally broken. Enough is enough. Today, I‚Äôm introducing the Fix Funding First Act ‚Äì a solution. #gapol

My Health Subcommittee examined proposals today to end surprise medical billing by protecting patients from payment disagreements between providers and insurers. An unplanned visit to the E.R. should never leave insured patients with thousands of dollars in debt.

Surprise medical bills occur when patients are caught between insurers and health care providers, and too often it leaves them with exorbitant debts that can wreak havoc on family finances when they learn they were treated by an out-of-network physician.
